item.title: Move Fast, but Obey the Rules: China’s Vision for Dominating A.I.
item.description: Beijing wants to lead the world in developing cutting-edge artificial intelligence, but it also wants companies to adhere to an increasingly complex set of rules.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Tommy Wang/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Executives at Zhipu AI, one of China’s most promising A.I. start-ups, alongside others, at a launch event at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange last month.

item.title: Squeezed Between Trump and China, India Looks for Faraway Friendships
item.description: India is overcoming its aversion to free-trade deals to cozy up with Canada and other middle powers.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Sajjad Hussain/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, center, met with Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, and António Costa, the president of the European Council, in New Delhi in January.

item.title: How Trump Appears in the Epstein Files
item.description: The New York Times found more than 5,300 files with references to Mr. Trump and related terms. They include salacious and unverified claims, as well as documents that had already been made public.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, Michael C. Bender and David Enrich
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump in the Oval Office on Friday.

item.title: U.A.E. Firm Quietly Took Stake in the Trump Family’s Crypto Company
item.description: The $500 million agreement raises new concerns about the propriety of the president negotiating foreign policy with his own business partners.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zach Witkoff, left, and Eric Trump, speaking in Dubai in May. Eric Trump signed an agreement with an Emirati-backed investment firm days before his father’s inauguration in January 2025.

item.title: Indonesia Lifts Ban on Grok After New Assurances From X Corp
item.description: Indonesia joined Malaysia and the Philippines in reversing its restrictions, weeks after it blocked the chatbot because it was used to generate sexually explicit images of real people.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: In this photo illustration, the Grok Imagine web page, which produces A.I.-generated images and video, is displayed on a computer screen.

item.title: Target’s New C.E.O. Faces Hometown Crisis as He Begins Turnaround Effort
item.description: Michael Fiddelke takes the top job at the struggling retailer amid continued unrest in the Twin Cities. A new boss also steps in at Walmart, where things are quieter.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Bryan Bedder/Getty Images for Target
item.media:description: As he prepared to take the top job at Target, Michael Fiddelke acknowledged that the company was in a tough situation.

item.title: Snow Drought in the West Reaches Record Levels
item.description: Warm temperatures and extremely low snowfall threaten water resources for the year.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins

item.title: Nestlé’s Chief Is in Turnaround Mode. He Drinks 8 Cups of Coffee a Day.
item.description: Philipp Navratil recently took over the 160-year-old Swiss food giant, charged with reviving growth and regaining trust after his predecessor was ousted over a scandal.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Clara Watt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Philipp Navratil took the top job at Nestlé in September, becoming its third chief executive in a less than two years.

item.title: Did A.I. Take Your Job? Or Was Your Employer ‘A.I.-Washing’?
item.description: As companies blame artificial intelligence for layoffs, skeptics wonder whether that explanation captures the full picture.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Melanie Lambrick

item.title: ‘I’m Free’: A Muslim Official Who Lost Faith in China Gains a Voice
item.description: Ma Ruilin worked as a Communist Party cadre helping fellow Muslims navigate their country as religious minorities, until the official hostility became too great to bear.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Owen Davies for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ma Ruilin praying in the basement of a halal restaurant where he works in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘Melania’ Arrives With Strong Box Office Showing for a Documentary
item.description: Amazon backed up the Brink’s trucks for the vanity film, resulting in weekend ticket sales of about $7 million in North America, enough for third place.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The first lady, Melania Trump, at a screening of “Melania” at the Kennedy Center in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Pentagon Defends Restrictions on Media Outlets
item.description: The purpose of the new rules is to “stop activity that could compromise national security,” the Defense Department said in response to a New York Times lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon imposed restrictions on media organizations in October, calling them a reasonable initiative to balance national security with media access.

item.title: The Latest Way to Create an Isolated Retreat: Buy a Whole Village
item.description: Wealthy buyers and tourism entrepreneurs are acquiring abandoned European villages — school, church and bar included.
item.dc:creator: Brent Crane

item.title: Kevin Warsh Has a Tough Job Ahead. It’s Not the First Time.
item.description: Mr. Warsh is known as a consensus builder, skills he will need if he is to head the Federal Reserve when President Trump is demanding rock-bottom rates.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Brendan McDermid/Reuters
item.media:description: The onus is on Kevin M. Warsh, President Trump’s pick to lead the Federal Reserve, to prove that he can run an institution under pressure.

item.title: A Hawkish Kevin Warsh at the Fed Could Haunt Bessent
item.description: The Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent tried to avoid providing President Trump with a clear recommendation to lead the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent led the vetting process for the next Federal Reserve chair.

item.title: Sell America Is the New Trade on Wall Street
item.description: Investors are increasingly souring on the United States, as illustrated by the declining dollar, the stalled stock market and rising government borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. stock market has plateaued in dollar terms since the start of the year and started to slide when measured in other currencies.

item.title: Energy Bills Have Soared Recently. How Can States Bring Costs Down?
item.description: Energy experts said that governors and legislatures have tools to keep electricity prices from rising further, and might even be able to lower them.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electricity rates have soared recently in most states.

item.title: For Hassett, Loyalty to Trump Became a Liability in Fed Race
item.description: Kevin A. Hassett had been seen as the front-runner in the Fed race, but his deep ties to the president raised questions about his independence.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has high expectations for Kevin A. Hassett.

item.title: Trump Names ‘Data Nerd’ to Lead Labor Statistics Agency
item.description: The decision to nominate Brett Matsumoto, a career government economist, came six months after the president fired the previous commissioner.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump fired the last Bureau of Labor Statistics commissioner because he said the monthly jobs report numbers had been “rigged.”

item.title: U.N. Says It’s in Danger of Financial Collapse Because of Members’ Unpaid Dues
item.description: The world body warned it would run out of money by July and have to close its New York headquarters if countries, namely the United States, did not pay annual dues that amount to billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The General Assembly in September. The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, sent a letter to the ambassadors of all 196 member states on Thursday saying, “I cannot overstate the urgency of the situation we now face.”

item.title: Jeff Bezos’s Rocket Company Blue Origin Pauses Space Tourism to Focus on the Moon
item.description: The New Shepard rocket from Blue Origin, which brought 92 people on trips to the edge of space, will cease flying for at least two years as the company prioritizes NASA contracts.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Trump’s Lawsuit Against I.R.S. Creates ‘Enormous Conflict of Interest’
item.description: The president is demanding that the federal government pay him at least $10 billion over the unauthorized disclosure of his tax returns during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump created what legal experts called an unparalleled situation of federal agencies facing a lawsuit from the head of the executive branch.

item.title: Who Is Trump’s New Fed Chair Pick?
item.description: President Trump announced Kevin Warsh as his nominee to succeed Jerome H. Powell as chair of the Federal Reserve. Our reporter Colby Smith explains why the choice matters for the economy.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith, Melanie Bencosme, Sutton Raphael, June Kim and Thomas Vollkommer

item.title: ‘Produce Pete’ Napolitano, a Fruit and Vegetable Celebrity, Dies at 80
item.description: For more than 30 years, he drew fans for dispensing weekly produce punditry on a New York television station, building on a sales career that began when he was 5.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Chris Maynard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Napolitano at his produce store in Bergenfield, N.J., in 2004. He offered advice about produce on a Saturday morning news program, reporting from farms, restaurants, pumpkin patches and corn fields.

item.title: How Strong Is Your Financial Knowledge? Take Our Quiz.
item.description: Test your knowledge of credit cards, buying a home, saving for college or retirement and other things that affect your wallet.
item.dc:creator: Connie Chang, Juli Fraga and Jay Daniel Wright
item.media:credit: Jay Daniel Wright

item.title: In a Bid to Kick-Start Growth, Britain Turns to China
item.description: Buffeted by tariffs and trade tensions, Prime Minister Keir Starmer took British business leaders to China and emerged with deals on visas and Scotch whisky, as well as pledges to deepen ties.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Carl Court/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, left, with President Xi Jinping of China, in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Kevin Warsh, Trump’s Choice for Fed Chair Could Find It Difficult to Deliver
item.description: Kevin M. Warsh, whom Mr. Trump tapped to become the next chair of the Federal Reserve, could face fierce resistance if he tries to pursue substantially lower borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Tesla’s Model S, Soon to Be History, Changed the Auto Industry
item.description: The company’s chief executive, Elon Musk, said this week that it would stop making the car, an electric pioneer in 2012, as well as the Model X.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Lexus Division of Toyota Motor Corp
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Model S was a breakthrough and ushered in quite a number of technologies people hadn’t seen before,” said Sam Abuelsamid, an executive at Telemetry, a Detroit communications and research firm.

item.title: Tips for Lowering Your Credit Card Interest Rate
item.description: The first step, consumer finance experts say, is to ask your card issuer to reduce the rate. And with average balances now $6,500, consider using your tax refund to put a dent in the debt.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: Your ‘Safe’ Stock Funds May Be Riskier Than You Think
item.description: The U.S. stock market has become so concentrated that even broad index funds are no longer well diversified, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Davide Bonazzi

item.title: A Challenge for Britain’s Royal Mail: Proving It Can Deliver the Mail
item.description: Late letters are causing distress to some in Britain and fueling criticism of its 500-year-old postal service.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Hannah Mckay/Reuters
item.media:description: Royal Mail workers unloading mail sacks in London last month.

item.title: Will Kevin Warsh Do What Trump Wants?
item.description: Some investors are worried that President Trump’s nominee to run the Federal Reserve may not be a guaranteed “yes” on cutting interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Brendan McDermid/Reuters
item.media:description: If confirmed by the Senate, Kevin Warsh would replace Jay Powell, whose term as Fed chairman expires in May.

item.title: Trump Picks Kevin Warsh as Next Fed Chair
item.description: If confirmed by the Senate, Kevin M. Warsh, a former governor at the central bank, will replace Jerome H. Powell, whose term as chair ends in May.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith, Tony Romm and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Kevin M. Warsh, a former Federal Reserve governor, was also a front-runner to lead the central bank during President Trump’s first term.

item.title: Chevron Points to Venezuela’s Promise as Big Oil Earnings Fall
item.description: The two largest U.S. oil companies, Chevron and Exxon Mobil, reported their lowest annual profits in years.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chevron refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.

item.title: Hollywood’s North Road Studio Acquired by the European Production Giant Mediawan
item.description: Peter Chernin, an industry veteran who founded North Road in 2022, said his deal with Mediawan met a need to get bigger in an era of consolidation.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: J. Emilio Flores for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Chernin, shown in 2014, will remain at North Road as nonexecutive chairman. “There is a real need for greater scale right now,” he said on Thursday.

item.title: How DoorDash and Other Food Delivery Apps Are Reshaping Mealtime in the U.S.
item.description: Almost three of every four restaurant orders in the U.S. weren’t eaten in a restaurant, according to recent data. We spoke to readers who are devoted to delivery but question the costs.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Food delivery took off during the pandemic, and since then has only grown in popularity.

item.title: Lukoil Gas Station Franchisees Caught in a Fight Between US and Russia
item.description: After the United States imposed sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil producers, the ripple effects wreaked havoc on business for local franchisees.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Lukoil gas station in New York City. In October, the Treasury Department put sanctions on Lukoil and another Russian oil company, Rosneft.

item.title: Can Josh D’Amaro Break Disney’s Succession Curse?
item.description: Josh D’Amaro is widely considered a front-runner to be the company’s next C.E.O. His biggest challenge might be escaping Bob Iger’s shadow.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: Disney, Walt, World (Lake Buena Vista, Fla)
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

item.title: Panamanian Court Strikes Down Hong Kong Firm’s Canal Contract
item.description: The ruling delivers a victory to President Trump, who has said he wants the U.S. to control the canal, and a blow to the longtime ports operator, CK Hutchison.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has frequently said he wants the United States to retake control of the Panama Canal.

item.title: Trump Is Expected to Announce Kevin Warsh as Fed Chair
item.description: President Trump is set to announce his choice to replace Jerome H. Powell as chair of the Federal Reserve, saying it is someone “known to everybody in the financial world.”
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Ann Saphir/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump is planning to announce Kevin M. Warsh, a former Federal Reserve governor, as his choice to replace Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: Washington Post Plans Cuts to Reshape Newsroom
item.description: The changes are expected to include significant layoffs in areas like sports and international coverage.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple, Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington Post’s newsroom in 2017.

item.title: California Jury Convicts Ex-Google Engineer of Stealing AI Secrets
item.description: A federal jury found that Linwei Ding stole thousands of confidential files to help him start a company in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The case is one of several that have surfaced in recent years against Chinese nationals in the United States as the fight for technological dominance ramps up.

item.title: Venezuelan Lawmakers Approve Sweeping Overhaul of Oil Sector
item.description: Bowing to Trump administration pressure, the new legislation improves conditions for foreign oil companies and opens the way to slash the taxes they pay.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of a hand holding a drilling rig near Venezuela’s state oil company last year.

item.title: Murdoch and News Corp Take on the West Coast with The California Post
item.description: The expansion of the Murdoch tabloid from its New York roots to the West Coast is the latest sign of the outlet’s national ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Photo-illustration by The New York Times; Photos: Getty Images

item.title: Founder of First Brands, Whose Bankruptcy Spooked Wall St., Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
item.description: Patrick James, who was earlier ousted from the beleaguered auto-parts maker, is accused by federal prosecutors of faking invoices and lying about hidden debt for years.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland

item.title: John L. Allen Jr., Journalist With Inside Access to the Vatican, Dies at 61
item.description: He seemed to know everyone at the Holy See, and it showed in his reporting for the National Catholic Reporter and his website, Crux, though some said he grew too close to his sources.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Karen Warren/Houston Chronicle, via Getty Images
item.media:description: John L. Allen Jr. in 2007. “From the end of the 20th century until his death, Allen was essential reading for anyone who cared about the inner workings of the Vatican,” a colleague said.

item.title: Costco Is Sued Over Preservatives in Its $5 Rotisserie Chickens
item.description: A proposed class-action lawsuit claims Costco was misleading customers and engaging in false advertising when it described the chicken as having no preservatives.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two plaintiffs in a lawsuit against Costco said they would not have bought rotisserie chickens if they knew they contained food additives.

item.title: Budget Hotels Become an Immigration Battleground for ICE Protests
item.description: “No sleep” protests have used noise and other tactics to target ICE agents at hotels, leaving the owners, often immigrants themselves, caught in the middle.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung and Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators took over the lobby of a Hilton Garden Inn in TriBeCa on Tuesday to show solidarity with anti-ICE protests in Minneapolis.

item.title: New Food Stamp Rules Are Confusing Grocery Stores and Consumers
item.description: A dizzying array of rules govern what can be bought with SNAP dollars, confusing grocery stores and consumers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell and Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens Despite Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The monthly trade deficit and imports rebounded in November after shrinking significantly in prior months, new data show.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
